author: Tina Moore
title: ACS had visited home where 1-year-old was found dead seven times | New York Post
text:
A 1-year-old girl was found dead in her crib on Staten Island — and her mother told cops the child has “tripped and hit her head on a coffee table,” cops said Tuesday.
There were no obvious signs of abuse on little Bianca Abdul’s body but her parents have been investigated over child abuse and neglect allegations at the home seven times in the past, police said.
A man identified by relatives as the child’s father was taken from the home in handcuffs Tuesday, but it was unclear if he was charged, according to the Staten Island Advance. 
A police source said the dad Joseph Abdul, 36, was taken into custody for violating an order of protection filed by a male relative of the baby’s mom, Leila Wade, 39.
Wade told investigators she found the baby lying face down in her crib on Moreland Avenue around 9:30 a.m. Monday, cops said.
EMS responded and took the tot to Staten Island University Hospital, where she was declared dead an hour later. The Medical Examiner’s Office will perform an autopsy to determine the cause of death.
Wade told investigators that her daughter had “tripped and hit her head on a coffee table” on Friday, cops said.
The child’s family had been investigated by the Administration for Children’s Services seven times previously over allegations of abuse and neglect in the home, police told The Post.
The agency investigated alleged drug use and inadequate supervision at the home on March 20, 2016, an unknown date in April 2015 and on Jan. 9, 2015, police said. All three allegations were. “Indicated,” which means the agency decided there was enough evidence of abuse and neglect.
The agency also investigated an allegation of inadequate supervision by the mom on July 20, 2016, drug abuse on May 22, 2014, and of education neglect in 2013. All three complaints were unsubstantiated.
Wade has two prior arrests, but both are sealed, sources said.
Abdul has 14 prior arrests. Six of them are sealed but the others were for violating orders of protection, assault and grand larceny.
Cops went to the home six times to respond to domestic violence complaints that the parents lodged against each other.
